posts.name: Justin| Alum|FRC 3035
posts.cooked: I was looking at old diagrams of robot power distribution diagrams and noticed the backup battery. This seems really great, how come it isnt allowed or used anymore?

posts.name: Justin| Alum|FRC 3035
posts.cooked:
Screenshot 2025-04-20 222441 1217×791 141 KB

Screenshot 2025-04-20 222441 1217×791 141 KB

Screenshot 2025-04-20 222441 1217×791 141 KB

Here is a screenshot of an example for those wondering

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
You gotta get the old fogeys for that one. First to understand why it WAS needed, and then to understand why it went away. Fortunately for you, or not, I might fit that description.

First: Why it WAS needed. WAY back in the early 2000s, there were occasionally, er, “issues” with robots that lost most but not all of their power. 330 spent most of their first IRI wandering across the field and then dying and then wandering and then dying, toasted batteries or so I recall hearing. Basically, if the controller voltage dipped too low, odd things would happen, and the E-Stops didn’t work properly because the controller would barely get the signal. You’ll notice that the controller is powered directly off of one of the power distribution board ports, with a full breaker.

So, in the mid 2000s (I want to say 2004 was the first season this happened in), IFI designed in a backup battery port. You’d charge your 7.2V battery, you’d plug it in, and the controller and radio would function enough to get signals and actually shut down properly.

So why did it go away? When the 8-slot cRIO was introduced in 2009, it came along with a slightly smarter power distribution board. (For anybody that has a blue power distribution panel: Yes, that one.) This particular PDB was built to specifically power the cRIO off of a dedicated branch circuit that ensured that enough voltage was supplied to the cRIO almost regardless of actual battery voltage. When the PDP and PDH and PDP2 came along, every single one of them did the same thing: Put the RIO (of whatever flavor) onto a dedicated power point, which was guaranteed to be the last thing to lose power.

So, short version: It’s no longer required for safety, because the power distribution board circuitry for powering the robot controller has an equivalent.

EricH:

PDP2 came along, every single one of them did the same thing:

The PDP2 is nothing more than a hunk of copper with some ports on it. Would this cause the same problems to happen again that warranted the backup battery? image 1057×455 97.5 KB

image 1057×455 97.5 KB

image 1057×455 97.5 KB

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: No, because the RoboRIO has internal voltage regulation and well-behaved undervoltage lockout logic that cleanly disables things before it completely loses power.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
EricH:

When the PDP and PDH and PDP2 came along, every single one of them did the same thing: Put the RIO (of whatever flavor) onto a dedicated power point, which was guaranteed to be the last thing to lose power.

They go have dedicated ports, but they’re straight battery voltage. The RIO brownout behavior and internal power management is what keeps it alive now.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked:
Oh man, really putting out the old-timer bat-signal for this one.

When we started using multiple CIM -motor drivetrains you could get nasty voltage drops, especially during high-torque moments like turning or pushing - this was exacerbated by using old batteries across multiple seasons with multiple deep-discharge / recharge cycles.

Back then, the robot controller was powered directly from the battery (and the radio was powered from this IFI robot controller). If the battery voltage dropped below about 7 volts for a brief moment, the robot controller would reset and then you’d have to wait for it to come back up and the field to re-connect to it. While these didn’t take as long as the modern RoboRio and VH radio to re-start, you’d have moments with no way to control the robot. This back-up battery made sure your controller wouldn’t reset during those brief voltage drops. You wouldn’t be able to move great when this happened - you wouldn’t have 12 v going to each speed controller and you probably were opening some 40 amp breakers - but you didn’t have to wait for the field to reconnect to each robot.

Today, if you put a cruddy old battery in your robot and try to do something that pulls a lot and causes a voltage drop, look at what happens at your driver station. The RoboRio / driverstation has this brown-out protection built in where it will disable motor outputs if the voltage gets too low. This way it protects itself from resetting (and the subsequent minute or so needed to reconnect) at the expense of your robot moving.

This software protection does the same thing, and in the end your robot would have the same performance issues if the voltage was allowed to drop below 7 volts but the RoboRio stayed up.

posts.name: gurellia53
posts.cooked:
I have some fleeting memory of the backup battery also being tied to some specific functionality - maybe servo power?

I may be completely misremembering, but it really feels like our '07 robot couldn’t deploy ramps (using a servo) without a backup battery.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
EricH:

This particular PDB was built to specifically power the cRIO off of a dedicated branch circuit that ensured that enough voltage was supplied to the cRIO almost regardless of actual battery voltage.

Peter_Johnson:

because the RoboRIO has internal voltage regulation

This is a big part of it: way back then, switching voltage regulators were expensive .  The price of low-Rds-on MOSFETs and integrated regulator controllers came way down over the 2000s and 2010s.

“Just tack on a second battery” was where the crossover point happened to be at that time.

gurellia53:

I have some fleeting memory of the backup battery also being tied to some specific functionality - maybe servo power?

Yes, it provided power to the PWM port power rail, which is where servos connected.  It didn’t matter for the Victor motor controllers, since they didn’t use the power pin, but it did matter for servos.
